messageBody:
Robert Watkins wrote:

> And if it's an obscure solution, which would actually work, why not
> promote it more? We're discussing the code _you_ can write, which _you_
> can control - if you want to have a runtime and API jar, only you are
> stopping you.

Pure pragmatism. Solutions based on language features are more likely to
be adopted than solutions based on extra-language design decisions.
Again, if extra-language conventions were enough, we wouldn't have
needed Java or C++. You can write object oriented code in C. You just
can't enforce it.

Apparently some people on this list believe they do want a language
without access protection. It would be interesting to explore such a
language, and if practice proved it useful, they might even convince me.
However, that would be a new language. not Java. Access protection is a
fairly fundamental part of Java. You'll have more success working with
the language than against it.
